message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a diagnosis of Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis. A biopsy of the lesion would most likely show a rich dermal inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly composed of CD4+ T cells. Scant dermal inflammatory infiltrate with macrophages and dendritic cells is more commonly seen in cutaneous T cell lymphoma. The presence of a subepidermal blister and a polymorphous inflammatory infiltrate with an eosinophilic predominance is seen in bullous pemphigoid. Mucin deposition in the dermal layer is seen in dermatomyositis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the patient’s recent MRSA skin infection suggest that the patient has developed Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS). Among the options, a rich dermal inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly composed of CD4+ T cells (Option B) is the most likely histopathologic feature found on the patient's biopsy in SJS. Option A, scant dermal inflammatory infiltrate, is not likely seen in SJS. Option C, subepidermal blister, and eosinophilic predominance is seen in bullous pemphigoid, not SJS. Option D, mucin deposition, is seen in cutaneous mucinosis, not SJS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest a diagnosis of hand-foot-and-mouth disease. The biopsy will show a rich dermal inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly composed of CD4+ T cells. Option A is not likely as it describes a scant dermal inflammatory infiltrate. Option C describes a subepidermal blister, which is not typically seen in hand-foot-and-mouth disease. Option D describes mucin deposition, which is not seen in hand-foot-and-mouth disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the physical examination described in the question suggest a possible diagnosis of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) or toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). The histopathologic features of SJS/TEN are characterized by a rich dermal inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly composed of CD4+ T cells. Option (C) is more characteristic of bullous pemphigoid, while options (A) and (D) are not relevant to the diagnosis of SJS/TEN.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and the appearance of the skin lesions suggest a diagnosis of hand, foot, and mouth disease, which is caused by Coxsackievirus A16. The most likely histopathologic feature of the biopsy is a rich dermal inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly composed of CD4+ T cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation suggests a diagnosis of hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD), which is caused by enterovirus. The exhibit shows the characteristic bullae and papules of HFMD. Histopathologic features of HFMD include a rich dermal inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly composed of CD4+ T cells. Therefore, the correct answer is (B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient has hand, foot and mouth disease, which is caused by a virus. Among the options, a rich dermal inflammatory infiltrate composed of CD4+ T cells is most likely to be found on biopsy. This is consistent with a viral etiology and the inflammatory skin lesions seen in the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with painful oral ulcers and rash, with multiple raised erythematous circular papules with a central bulla occupying <10% of BSA. The most likely diagnosis is Stevens-Johnson syndrome or toxic epidermal necrolysis. Among the options, the histopathologic feature most likely to be found on a biopsy is a rich dermal inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly composed of CD4+ T cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described are consistent with the diagnosis of Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis (SJS/TEN). The histopathologic features of SJS/TEN include a rich dermal inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly composed of CD4+ T cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The exhibit shows multiple raised erythematous circular papules, which are characteristic of erythema multiforme. The oral ulcers and mucosal erosions are also consistent with this diagnosis. Histopathologic features of erythema multiforme include a rich dermal inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly composed of CD4+ T cells.
